author: oaklandmatt
content:
📖 story time:

Arguably one of the most important things I did in my career was a last minute instrumental version of "I Love Rock N Roll" for an A&R at Syco in the US for some random contestant on the short-lived US version of the X Factor. I crushed it on a deadline, then that same A&R hired me a year later to work on a band called Emblem 3 who was on X Factor US as well. I crushed that and then six months after that he recommended me to a UK A&R who was having trouble finishing a song for One Direction. I did a spec production on the song Best Song Ever and they liked it and used it and all of a sudden I become a big pop producer. Stemming from doing an great job on some instrumental cover for a dumb singing tv show.

author: philbarnes
content:
One of my favorite TLA experiences is when I (unknowingly) fucked up a drum edit in a song I sent him to mix about 6 years ago. 

Got a voicemail from a South Beach number that said "Phil! Tom Lord-Alge here. Hey, thank you for those stems. Give me a call when you get a chance would ya?" 

Not knowing my demise, I thought I would flex and call him in front of my gf on speakerphone where the first words out of his mouth were: "Thanks for sending those stems so fast. But these drums... are absolutely FUCKED. I could fix it for you, but I'm not going to, you're a professional engineer, figure it out." 

Needless to say I stayed up all night figuring it out, found my mistake and I like to think we're on better terms now.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Loving your job 80% of the time is a phenomenal, compared to the general public. 

One thing I’m amazed by working with Cian & Rollmottle is their endless capacity for positivity during a project. No matter how shitty my delivery or communication, they approach things with a smile and a sense of humor. I’ve literally never heard either of them complain. I thought commiserating about shitty aspects of a gig was a part of professionalism, but they have me rethinking things. 

In my own projects, when I approach clients with patience and curiosity, I find that not only are they happier faster, I’m happier the whole time. It’s SO MUCH EASIER to say “let’s try it” than to say “here’s why that’s not a good idea.” I find I learn a lot that way too. 

In any case, going back in to fix or add only bugs me when I think I’m supposed to be done. If I can stay open, then opening a session feels a lot easier. 

So I guess my advice is: you might have fewer problem clients if you try to remember they’re not problems to solve, they’re people to serve.

author: bobby k

Most of my years in music have felt like groundwork-laying years. Just because your credits playlist isn’t looking the way you’d like doesn’t mean that growth wasn’t happening. I would challenge you to reflect on where you started 2025 and where you are now and take inventory of what growth or lessons you experienced. 

The most rewarding bits of this year for me wouldn’t make sense to post about. Paid off my first business loan. Improved the efficiency of signal flow in my studio. Learned to fix some gear. Stood up for myself in a hard conversation with some assholes trying to rip me off. Got out of the UAD ecosystem. 

None of that I’m posting about or adding to a playlist, but it feels just as essential (or more) to my business than the songs that got released.

author: BatMeckley
content: When I was a kid I was super into magic, and had the good fortune of getting to spend a week with Penn and Teller in Atlantic City. The things that stuck out to me most was not just how continuously dedicated to their craft they were (Teller would routinely walk around with stacks of coins in his hand so he’d know exactly how it was supposed to look and feel when he was only pretending they were there) but how fiercely pragmatic they were. They’d stay on the 13th floor, walk under ladders, whistle at night… they were ferociously unsuperstitious. They weren’t counting on fate or luck, they were counting on work and the talent that stems from that. That always stuck with me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It sounds like you're using their browser site to navigate your files, correct? I hate to say it but that's clunky as hell and you may as well be using Google Drive at that point (No!). Using Dropbox in-browser to navigate should be a last resort.

The move here is to connect Dropbox with your desktop so that your Dropbox folder appears and functions like any other folder in your Finder window. It will be far far easier to manage your files this way because they now have all of the same navigation functionality as your local files. 

I understand your desire not to download everything from your DB to your local drive. That's an easy thing to control once you wrap your head around how selective sync works. Once you get DB set up on your desktop you can specify that nothing should be downloaded to your local drive unless you specify (online-only), but you will still be able to see all of the cloud files inside of your DB folder in the Finder.

If you decide you want to download a file to your local drive you can right-click on the file and tell it to download (make available offline). And if later you decide to remove it from your local drive and make it cloud-only you can select "make online only". It's pretty simple once you get up to speed on the workflow.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok gang, here’s something I’ve been pondering

Imagine 3 sliders that go from 0 to 10. Your goal is to set the sliders to maximize your wellbeing (in the broadest sense) and the wellbeing of those close to  you. The sliders are in effect zero sum, in that the closer you are to one end then less you have of the attribute on the other end. Let’s set the time horizon to 25 years and acknowledge the seemingly increasing pace of change in the world

Ok, the sliders …

**#1 Classics vs Cutting Edge**
On this slider 0 represents maximum knowledge in a classical sense - literature, math, mythology, fundamental accepted basics in Biology/Chemistry/Physics etc etc. 10 represents complete literacy in the cutting edge of culture, science and technology - from memes and Reddit culture to AI to synthetic biology and Blockchain etc etc 

**#2 Specialist vs Generalist**
Here 0 represents a very deep and specific knowledge of a chosen field (could be a doctor or a producer) vs 10 representing a modern Jack of all trades who knows a little bit about a lot of things 

**#3 Short Term vs Long Term**
On the slider 0 represents a disposition all about short term wins, fast plays that close out over a year vs 10 representing long investments in a given idea/field/belief system

It goes without saying that the zero sum aspect here is artificial, you can of course have some long term plays happening alongside some short term, but it’s just to get the juices flowing

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Coincidentally I was exploring a similar idea this morning. I'm on a David Bohm kick and was reading his book 'On Dialogue' and recently finished his 'On Creativity' (would highly recommend both).

In 'On Dialogue' he gives an example I think can be repurposed here. Imagine a song being presented to us. An external signal. When it reaches us it makes contact with what Bohm calls the "whole movement of thought". The thinking and feeling apparatus within us is activated. Thoughts and 'felts' are said to be fundamentally created from memory. Upon contact a 're-presentation' is created where the activity of our thought and feeling reforms the event internally. The 'net presentation' is the fused result. 'Mis-representation' occurs when we mistake the 'net presentation' for the original.

I was thinking on all this and how it might connect to your comment from yesterday, "I told Jon that I don't think he's ever brought more to an album, but also left less of his fingerprints on it".

Bohm brings up Michael Polanyi's idea of tacit knowledge. This is the always running in the background implicit structure we attend to music from, which makes 're-presentation' possible. This includes nostalgia for records we love, perceptual training, bodily memory, tolerance for brightness, etc... Implied here is that this is something you cannot turn off but can cultivate greater awareness off in disciplined participation with art. Polanyi says we attend from subsidiaries to a focal whole. If you start attending to your own sonic fingerprint as the focal object, the structure may collapse. So perhaps Jon was able to integrate a remarkable tacit contribution while being sensitive to the pre-existing structure and coherence of the whole. Maybe coherence and truth have similar meanings here?

Downstream of the artist's origination maybe 'truth' in record making is deep tacit integration, suspending egoic domination, and sensitivity to the internal structure / coherence of the original whole.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: bobby k
content:
Been pondering..a few thoughts:
-prioritizing health & productivity are not mutually exclusive, in fact they are easily aligned. A shorter work day that began with a workout is almost always more fruitful than a longer day grinding away
-not everything needs to be said with words, not everything needs to be a conversation. body language, silence, or taking initiative on a task all do a lot on their own. 
-deep breaths and letting the emotions process and pass before responding almost always yields a better interaction, in business and in relationships
-nobody really needs to know how hard you worked.
-you’re not Superman, there will be things left unfinished each day (music/work, house projects/house chores). Having a system of prioritizing helps foster peace with the unfinished stuff

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: BatMeckley
content: I do think things like ozone, soothe, gulfoss allow inexperienced engineers to get close to what they want to hear without knowing what it is they’re doing, which is where a lot of the problem lies. If you slap soothe on a vocal it will start indiscriminately nuking resonances whether you like them or not, whether they’re useful or not. An experienced engineer will spot a problem frequency, eq it out, or sometimes multiband it. But ANYONE can slap soothe on without much knowledge of where the problem is, and have it “fix” it, while at the same time neutering everything else. (Also, setting up mixes where everything is the same “flat” leading to these awful mixes that sound like a 2 trk and a vocal stem, rather than a cohesive record.

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: cian riordan
content: On this note, I'll say that I LOVE these drives. My workflow in the past has basically been to buy a new 1GB SSD drive every few projects. When I had my setup on a laptop, this allowed me to always have access to projects I was working on the go (printing stems on the couch while watching TV? Yes please). In addition to using these SSDs, I'd always keep local backups with 'Sync Folders Pro' -- RIP Sync X -- on a cheaper, larger capacity USB drive. Being an anxious data archiver, I also signed up for Backblaze a few years ago as a cloud solution in case my studio burns down. Its a really great service, but the caveat they have with your drives is you *can* back up externals, they just need to be connected to your computer every 30 days. So I bought this monster USB3 hub and just had all of these fucking SSDs connected to my computer whenever it was setup at my studio. It worked fine for a few years, but I ran out of space again a few weeks ago and decided to futureproof mysetup a little bit. I ended up getting a thunderbolt Drobo. That way, I could have redundant storage for archived projects (which also gets uploaded to backblaze) but without having 16 drives on my desktop. Now I just have two of those samsung SSDs -- one work, and one as a backup. They run lightning fast and I get to keep having local backups in case I fuck the dog moving files around after a few glasses of wine. Then, when I run out of space, I just offload onto the Drobo and it's locally redundant, and also backed up on the cloud. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good way to summarize the benefit of Andrej's approach here is by looking at two different ways to go about learning how a frog works: 

1) You can dissect a frog to learn about it. You observe the long legs, the muscles, the skin, the eyes, the respiratory system, etc. You see it's strengths and you see it's weaknesses and you draw your conclusions from there. This would be the top-down learning approach. It's good at describing what already *is*. 

Or...

2) You build/design a frog from scratch. You will quickly come to understand why things *have* to be the way they are. You realize that all of the evolutionary "choices" about a frog's physiology are simply the best possible compromises, given the pressures of the environment, the availability of resources, and the limits of physics. By building it yourself you will come to perceive all of the invisible challenges and "solved" problems that were required to make an organism that will simply survive, much less thrive.

This firsthand experience of building the thing will actually make you an expert because you've done the hard work and experienced it for yourself. You took ten paths to failure and made every mistake before settling on a a non-obvious compromise that allows you to balance it against every other factor. You understand *why* it needs to be that way.

This knowledge will make you robust and flexible, whereas top-down knowledge is more superficial and brittle. If the conditions of your subject change and the model you understand is no longer relevant then you're in a far more precarious place than someone who's built something from the ground up.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Schedule, schedule, schedule. I use a productivity app called Notion. Make multiple bottles ahead of time. That way you don’t have to stop working to make a bottle. You can pull them out of the refrigerator whenever you need, warm em up and you’re good to go. Most formula last at least 24 hours in the refrigerator. Breast milk is easier to work with because you can freeze it, grab it, and thaw it when you’re ready to use it. Plan your breaks around feeding. When he’s playing or napping, you can work. Make sure he’s visible tho. Have a bassinet, bouncer, or something next to your chair. Open backs help when mixing because you can hear if he cries. Babies love white noise. Play that shit on loop while he sleeps and he’ll be out for hours at a time. Use brown switches for your keyboard if you can get them. Those are extremely quiet and won’t wake the baby. 

That’s off of the top of my head. I might think of something else and add it here. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Bear in mind also that the references are UK specific, and this is a work in progress.


- A Minimum Rate Card (a reference for minimum per-hour and per-day rates, according to role and project budget, with additional minimum fees for equipment rental). As an example, see the current BECTU Production Sound rate card https://members.bectu.org.uk/filegrab/bectu-production-sound-rates-nov-2021-final.pdf?ref=2606

- Standardised working hours and breaks

- Minimum time off between working days, with breaches (“overnight infringement”) incurring additional fees for freelancers, or days-off in lieu for contracted workers

- Guaranteed minimum rates of overtime pay

- Special rates of pay for bank holidays

- An enforced system to credit all workers for their contributions – runners, assistants, ops, and engineers (think the credits at the end of a movie)

- Special rates of pay for weekends [Sunday bonus rates (but not Saturdays) are common in theatre. Some other industries pay weekends at time-and-a-half]

- Special rates of pay for planned overnight sessions [This is also common in theatre, film and tv, enforced by BECTU in those instances]

author: popthetrunk

It’s a file server, basically a non-*racle ZFS storage appliance tuned for audio. 

Custom BSD kernel with some hardening. Supermicro, AMD, Samsung, SKhynix, Solidigm, Micron, Seagate, LSI components - it’s quiet, resilient and performant, but it is not cheap. Anyone that has used ZFS knows it’s the star of the show here. And the hard won operator-of-this-specific-system documentation for any and all troubleshooting, maintenance, replacement on-prem + a reasonable upgrade roadmap with minimal downtime.

author: kieronmenzies
content: Hey this has been a fun discussion to read through. Just to add one more angle to the mix: most of you have been referring to agency as some kind of positive trait that you either have or you don’t have it — almost commodifying it. What if we think of agency, or the qualities of having agency no matter what term we use, as the norm? As in EVERYONE has it. And whether or not we are able to fulfill those qualities and/or desires is due to limiting factors, whether they are external forces (class system, institutional racism, gender discrimination, war, peer pressure, financial hardship, lack of resources, etc) or internal struggles (fear, self-doubt, depression, addiction, laziness, inner saboteur, etc) or any combination thereof. I know it’s totally idealistic but maybe if we’re able to think of everyone as being just as capable as the next -- instead of an “either-you-got-it-or-you-don’t” kind of way, especially in terms of “agency” which sounds like a corporate buzzword du jour -- then we’d be able to focus on and address the aspects of our societal constructs and daily lives that restrict our opportunities to succeed/work/create/thrive/survive/exist.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: peterlabberton
content: Thinking about numbers, i.e. a 2 db boost vs 4 db, and then endlessly ABing/being conservative with moves to a fault. At my old staff engineer gig I got to assist Joe Chiccarelli on a handful of tracking/mixing sessions. The most eye opening was assisting him mixing the latest Hellogoodbye record. He’d mix 2 songs a day on average, and just breeze through cranking on the 550 eqs in the console—not a care in the world what the numbers said. I’d take recall notes and print stems/various mixes and he and the band would go have lunch/dinner. Seeing him repeatedly just crank on shit until it sounded compelling was huge. Obviously, you need to have developed the instincts to do that tastefully and have it sound great, but that sent me down a path of being fearless and trying to not get hung up on looking at shit.

author: cian riordan

Some are just printed WAVs from a long distant version of Pro Tools with plugins that don't exist. Luckily I had the foresight to print versions without my obscenely loud 2013 master chain. Some of more recent PT sessions open right up and play back perfectly. The real question is how much to fuck with them before sending them off. When is enough, enough? I've rocked some these mixes around town in my car for almost a decade. It almost feels wrong to mess with the mixes, but there's just so much that can be improved upon. Makes me realize how much of the work we do is emotional and not just technical. Sure, I could improve the low end on a mix, modernize it... but is it worth it?

author: Will Melones
content: It's worth keeping in mind that there are living tortoises that have been around longer than the 'music industry' we know. For all the centuries before that it was just a thing that regular people participated in. Wealthy people had pianos in their homes and many knew how to play them. There was no Elvis or Britney Spears. For a while music publishing was literally the printing of sheet music. So maybe it's more crazy to think that there was recently this blip in time when people valued music enough to pay money to own it on little circles and cram into an arena to watch somebody sing on a jumbotron. It sounds kinda like claiming ownership of the sky if you think of art that way.

author: Rollmottle
content: as a fellow recovering Catholic, that music is imprinted in my DNA....Sister Tang was our music teacher and would teach us singing and dancing and would bring in Cure records and other 80s bangers for us to listen to and do dance routines to. the biggest shocker was every year at a single Christmas mass when our quiet little music teacher would do a solo vocal performance of Silent Night accompanied only by an organist and the church's reverb. what came out of her was earth-shatteringly stunning, bigger than life and visceral. you could hear a pin drop when she was through and the priest would just sit in that silence for an extra beat. one of my most vivid musical memories.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
I don't have time to jam on this today, we're gonna need a bigger boat if we were to really dig into that. It's already getting convoluted, and I sense multiple definitions of a number of the terms swirling around here. Your assumption about the Euro's assumption about people advocating agency (sigh, as I said, convoluted) is entirely off as far as I perceive it/think myself.

I feel you're conflating the act of actual possesing agency, ie 
"Is there a class of person for whom more agency would be a negative? I can’t think of one bar criminals" and the actual implications that stem from broadly viewing the world and other people through that lens, how it makes you think, what it makes you do, what considerations you make and don't make.

author: David Fuller
content:
a (basically useless in reality) alternate way of encoding digital audio; PDM instead of PCM. One bit, super high sample rates to noise shape all the quantization noise up above the audible range. Unfortunately, you can't really... do anything other than play it back. Doing any processing - including fades - has to be converted to PCM and then back. 

In other words, a solution looking for a problem, and a lot of home audio enthusiasts are enamored with it via marketing.

author: Slow Hand
content: You guys know that phenomenon where you can watch a car on the highway next to you and when you stare at it's hubcaps they look like they're spinning backwards? Did anyone ever realize that that's simply your eyes aliasing? It seems the "sample rate" of our eyes is too slow to catch up with a wheel spinning at highway speeds. We're perceiving the tire after it's already done almost a full revolution and we see it in the position *behind* where it once was. Hence the perception of spinning backwards. It's the same thing with audio. If the sample rate isn't fast enough it reads the super-high frequencies as being lower than they actually are.

Yeah. The next thing I was going to mention is that almost every file of mine gets prepended with the date: YYMMDD.

So files I generate today are prepended with 230128. This way every time I bounce a song or write a note my files automatically sort themselves chronologically.

author: popthetrunk
content:
That’s still correct.

APFS (case sensitive)for ssd , MacOS Extended (Journaled, Case Sensitive) ((This is HFS+)) for HDD or if you need your ssd to be backwards compatible on MacOS. 

This is because APFS is copy on write, so when you modify a file it writes changes to a new block as opposed to overwriting the same block already occupied by your data and journaling, those formerly accounted for blocks are referenced in a read only format called a snapshot which give built in file versioning, this makes disk fragmentation happen all of the time - which is a feature for an SSD. 

For an HDD this can lead to thrashing and early mechanical failure as well as the file system getting slower and slower over time due to more fragmentation. But, this is not really an issue if being used as a backup as opposed to active data, however you can’t create new Time Machine backups to an HFS+ formatted drive since Monterey iirc.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: Slow Hand
content:
Mmhm. At first glance the obvious move seems to be that Spotify could double its subscription rate to $20/month and kick a larger margin towards the artist. I think unlimited music is certainly worth that. Setting aside, for the moment, all of the other complexities around market pricing, we also need to remember that Spotify's largest streaming competitors are Apple and Amazon.

These are companies with massive war-chests derived from the success of their non-streaming companies. Even if Spotify *wanted* to raise the cost of their service, companies like Apple and Amazon can afford to keep the price of streaming services depressed and sustain a loss on their streaming services for far longer than Spotify ever could. To my eyes, Spotify doesn't have a whole lot of wiggle-room to adjust their pricing and therefore their payout models.

I say as much, because in casual discussions around streaming payouts, there doesn't seem to be much awareness of the larger business ecosystem that a company like Spotify finds itself in.

author: austenballard
content:
a number of years ago I consulted on a music tech curriculum for grades 10-12, these were some of the key points:

- Teach the fundamentals, always in a practical way. E.g. "Today we're going to record ourselves speaking" - briefly introduce how a microphone works, what a preamp is, and then get them recording each other. Same with EQ, Compressor, Reverb, Delay, etc.

- Use as many examples from current pop music as possible. Does someone in the class sing or rap? Have the students go through assembling a vocal chain with a compressor, EQ, etc. and record part of a song.

- Don't get too far in the weeds where it's not necessary. High schoolers DO need to know why we have different sample rates and bit depths. They DON'T need to know about aliasing, oversampling, clocking, or dither algorithms.

- Bring history in for context, but don't dwell on it. It's cool to know that we used to need a speaker in an echoey room or a giant metal plate to make a reverb, but focus on how and why they're using effects rather than where they came from

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly on pure sonics AT graph is still the best sounding to me, and if Im on a song with a great singer and a great take and just need to tweak a word or two I’ll just audio suite it and call it a day. 

To answer an above question I just bounce out a 2 track instrumental, and import that into Melo as ref track up top, set the tempo, import however many stacks of vocals and get to work.  When doing it this way MD  stand-alone has the edge over the plug-in because it’s all right there in front of me. It’s easy to visually reference a quad tracked lead vocal, and then align and de ess or consonant 8 harmonies. That’s where the stand-alone really shines, is massively dense stacks vocals like that, and not having to keep opening up a plug-in to change a different part or vibrato or formant of a particular track  of the stack or what not. Especially once you get the groove locked in on the lead, it’s just so easy to make all other 30 tracks lock in with it. 

For a solo vocal soul song? I’m probably just audio suiting AT in graph mode in PT. It ultimately sounds the best.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve been using a nice workflow for AirPod checks recently.

1. Have an output from your monitor/output bus (I have it on a send in my template) to PT Bridge

2. Open QuickTime and open a new audio recording (Cmd + shift + N). 

3. Select PT Bridge as the QuickTime audio input. Turn up the volume slider to monitor

4. Select AirPods as system output 


Hey presto. Works great, no need to stream to phone etc. Just have to remember to turn down that QuickTime volume slider when you flip back to speakers. Also I occasionally accidentally start QT audio recording with spacebar when meaning to hit play in Tools. No biggie 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Deleted User
content:
Spotify was not even supposed to be a paid service… their model and vision was never having to pay for music again; and letting THAT be high quality experience as if you are playing records you bought. They did indeed do that, and I don’t think it will go back. 

It was decentralization they were after. the record industry was already beyond rescue (to go back to its heyday) so they wanted a better piratesbay where people can hear the music right away, and not the messed up mp3 that has been converted to different codecs multiple times. The platforms opening up to everybody is why someone like myself or my clients can upload any kind of music. 

I mention all of this to say… I think that’s what they wanted. But I think they were hoping more people would use the free version so they can juice more profit out of the ads. I don’t think they were expecting this many people to go premium, which lowers the value of each ads… (because they won’t be listened to as much)

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

I did this successfully many years ago.  You need to NOT do anything with the card. Lock it. Then find a hex editor to look at the files with missing headers. Or...  something like that. author: ALXCPH
content: our whole tuning systems is based on the harmonic series of stacking 5ths. because nature gives us exactly that through the overtone series. but the higher you go the more "out of tune" it goes. back in the day, before we were able to make octave, and divide them into 12 notes, you would have the concept of a low E and a High E as they wouldnt sound "in tune" when trying to find the octave though stacking 5ths or thirds or fourths or what ever interval people tried to use. we chose 5ths at is was the closest one to looping while being somewhat in tune, and the we invented 12 tone equal temperment and made compromises on each note so that the notes would loop every 12 tones.

author: ehutton21
content:
If you’re confident enough to hit various scales spanning 2+ octaves in each hand (in sync and delayed/one at a time) and you have a decently strong level of piano sight reading ability, then I’d say a piano teacher might be worth lessons every so often if it’s affordable because I’d say you’re starting to max the limits of your ability to assess your execution of technique (you’ll want someone to actually watch how you move, see where you should go, and give you specific cues on what you can shore up from there). 

But honestly when I was training classical piano regularly as a kid (good god I feel old saying that but I know I’m not lol), majority of upper level technique mishaps stemmed from struggles with proper wrist & elbow position where students would let their form slide (the more advanced the composition you were playing, the harder it became to remember your technique) and so they’d lack the actual strength and muscle twitch to hit harder moves.   That along with finger strength & dexterity would often result in stumbles or slips, which also vary based on how you strike the key. Most common error you’ll see that slows down technique is wrists dipping below the fingers a la traditional keyboard typing at any point in the playing process, and you’re never gonna swing an arpeggio or move fast enough to trill because your physical relation to the keys is what dictates proficiency. The physical aspect is why pianists are brought in so young (I started at supervised playing at 4 and I started instruction when I could get through the alphabet), because you can shape them into technique machines. 

So if you’re looking for max utility, finger drills, wrist position, and scales as much as possible is going to keep you sharp as hell.

author: ehutton21
content:
I feel like budgeting expenses to see what you’re actually looking at and what you actually need down to the last dollar and cent (as crazy as it sounds, it can be done fairly accurately, and some banks/creditors even provider a CVS file for excel usage of spending logs) and figuring out how to get to your breakeven point every single month eliminates a lot of angst, and often times it’s not as crazy as you think. I’m not quite in LA, my move there is next month end of September, but CoL in San Diego is nearly identical to LA in most ways. Once I put my shit into an excel spreadsheet and did the math on “this is break even; this is what it looks like if I go out every once and a while; this is what it looks like if I’m off my rocker with my credit card” I could put rather definitive numbers on things and it gave me peace of mind.

As for more of the how: I think gaming the roommate system is your best bet. I’m moving into a two bedroom place with my roommate/collaborator as well as my long time girlfriend. If you can find a way to split a bedroom, that’s gonna help. 2 bed room houses for rent aren’t that bad if you’re willing to sit down with a drink or two on Zillow for a few nights and really figure out your living area. I’ve found places for the $2300 in East LA and Pasadena. Splitting that and other key living expenses (we plan to have a few nights where we eat together and we’ll sorta rotate meal ideas, that way everyone’s not shelling out super ridiculous individual grocery charges) among 3 people each month is fairly easy so long as we hustle well.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Observing others' conversations on the matter, it seems that Chat GPT still has lots of limitations when it comes to coding. Currently it lacks certain contextual awareness about how a part fits into a larger design/ecosystem, and so it's guidance on how to code or design something may be limited to low level coding at the moment.

I've got some friends experimenting with using it to generate content for their Dungeons and Dragons game and while it's been good about generating serviceable scenarios and providing responses to player choices, another limitation that they've encountered is that it doesn't remember things like player state (what was their health when we started, what is their location, etc). That is to say it lacks certain kinds of long-term memory that allow it to maintain continuity.

author: shaunobi
content: There’s an idea in software of “proxy based estimation”. So you collect a history of details about past projects. You have to track your time and clock in and out to have the data. So maybe you know past similar “X’s” took 9 hours on average, or 45 minutes. And you know you work X hours on average a day the last month (I usually take a three month average). And you can then bounce a project quickly up against your estimation process (for me it’s a hundred lines in a spreadsheet and some processing based on team composition but could just be 5 lines in a spreadsheet) in near real-time and get a number of hours. You then take that, apply it to your schedule, readjust your plan if needed (ie to accommodate clients with deadlines or other constraints) and let everyone know the plan. Get fast at it and you’ll always have a smooth backlog of work and never have to work more than X hours a day. That’s the theory anyway 😂

author: Deleted User
content:
Fair enough. Everything that concerns “me” starts with working on myself. 

But my belief as someone who makes art; it is my job to be concerned about it, and spend time pondering on it. I’m not responsible or I can’t be for it, it would be an arrogance and narcissism (or ego centric frame of mind at the very least) to believe that I’m responsible for it or matters in any way - but I think believing that what I do would have no impact on others is inconsiderate. 

I believe it would help people find things they like if everyone alivned their taste/values to their individuality; rather than the idea of their individuality.

Re: Korea; 
you bring up a very good point about this. Korea is an extreme case of collectivism over individualism, and my obsession about this probably stems from growing up in that background. I only truly understand two cultures from first hand experience and that is Korean and North American; but it seems that no matter how culture forms, human nature will always be relevant and it’s in our nature to be want to be accepted, feel included. 

I believe that American individualist propaganda is a lie. It’s not about being yourself, it’s rather about finding a box to put yourself in for sake of convenience. i believe it mostly has to do with consumerism and the complexity of the society from immigration and various cultures coming together; converging / diverging at different pace even amongst those that share the same cultural roots- which then later becomes nu-gen X-American culture, which is different from the culture of X. (X being a country/ethnic group)

Great and timely convo for me - I'm in LA next week and still hadn't booked a car. 

Heads up on Turo fine print:

"It’s very unlikely that your credit card company provides coverage for damage to a car booked through Turo. It’s even less likely that it provides liability coverage for injuries or damage you may cause to other people or their property. "

You still get the convenience of dealing with an individual/smaller company and the pickup/dropoff and knowing what vehicle you are getting, but price wise if you are risk-averse like me adding even the basic coverage bumps a Turo rental up into Hertz/Enterprise territory for my trip.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
**-) **Offline experiences might be a song or an artist being tied to a memory I cherish - that song played at that party when I kissed a beautiful girl, that song played when I was walking out of the bar piss drunk at 6 am with my best friends, that song I heard when I was at a music festival 10 years ago and the world was a better place etc, that song makes me laugh my ass off everytime I hear it (shoutout Frank Zappa lol)

**-) **It could also simply be a piece that moved me when I first heard it and it made me feel something - take for instance** LCD Soundsystem's** *"All My Friends"*, which is to me still the most poignant anthem about getting older, and it never fails to illicit and emotional reaction in me, even though I've never seen them live or have a specific memory attached to them. 

**-) **What makes me become a fan of an artist is - at least these days -  mostly determined by how consistently the artist's work can get an emotional reaction out of me. Take **Bleachers** for example - I had been aware of them for years, but only with this year's album and after discovering "Hey, their songs are actually ALL that good" I became a fan. 

**-)** There are a only a handful of bands/artists I consider myself a hardcore fan of., where I truly explored their entire catalogue over and over again, and it was almost always because they just continued to impress or move me

author: oaklandmatt
content:
as usual @cian riordan's got a great detailed response. I would just add that the more organized you are, the better everything will be in the long run. Having a solid system for mix versions and notes (both their notes on your mixes and your notes on your updates) will save you a lot of time and headache.

Also, differing opinions within a project (btw, this is most projects) usually sort themselves out by just hearing the different ideas. To piggyback off what @peterlabberton said, when I mix, I rarely need to be a tiebreaker. Most of those situations get decided by delivering a mix update with two options. Just do the teeny bit of extra work and give them options, and they'll usually decide amongst themselves.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I don't wanna talk bad about anyone but I've been following kneesovertoesguy for a good few years, even though I agree with alot of what he says I'd be careful with him for sure, he used to have a really good system with ATG and good coaches around him, but they've since left him and he's become alot more of a business man than a coach I feel, I know his training works for him and some others but it definitely isn't 1 size fits all, I know personally people that  have signed up to his programmes and have gotten much worse knees than they went in with, and when they asked him about it they were blocked on everything by him.. There's a lot of people out there with similar unconventional principles to him (like putting load thru knees over toes and back flexion etc) but are definitely much more educated on the topics they're speaking on, and won't block you when you confront them..

Id personally reccomend the likes of Jeffery Wolfe (@theflexibull), moses Bernard (@mosesbernard), Dan van zandt (@flexibility.research), Nicholas Simpson (@nicholassimpson_)

I've reached out to them before and they're always very helpful, nice people, I know they often do live videos themselves, maybe it could be worth asking one of them to do a podcast with you..
I definitely don't consider myself an expert on this stuff, but I feel I have a very good base knowledge on health and fitness, I've been heavily involved in track and feild most my life, competed internationally too, so keeping strong, flexible and pain free is definitely something I've experience in lol

author: Dodgy
content: Also, is there a particular level I should set the mic gain on the interface? It seems like it comes in really low. Is it better to record low and boost in DAW or increase mic gain (phantom power is on, a lot of my songs are softer delivery)

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: David Fuller
content:
Anyway: uncompressed PCM audio (.wav and .aiff) is made up of digital words generally 16 or 24 bits long recorded however many times a second for a given sample rate, for fixed point (integer) values. Each bit represents ~6dB of dynamic range. Every time you go up in level 6dB from that particular sample point, another bit flips from 0 (off) to 1 (on). The least significant bit defines your noise floor, so 16 bit audio has 96dB of dynamic range at maximum from noise floor to full scale (every bit turned on). Seems simple enough, right? And it isn't super complicated. But it has one problem: you run out of dynamic range real quick if you're changing levels with (virtual) faders at 24 bits. There are two ways around that:
1, make the mixer engine run on a much higher integer word length (like old Pro Tools HD systems, which use 48 bit integer), and the mixer automatically converts the audio (if anything is done to it, including fader moves) to 48 bit. Think of this as adding more digits to the fractions side of a decimal point. 
2, make the mixer engine run on a floating point system (almost every other DAW, including more modern versions of Pro Tools) - that is, you move *where the decimal point is* . 32 bit float effectively works as 24 bits that can be moved around more or less with impunity, up or down.

author: hendrick
content:
I agree with matt that hiring a mastering engineer is a luxury in the present day tbh. Most of the records that I get to mix or produce I'm expected to deliver a finished product ready to release. However when a lot of things are at stake (label release) it's almost 100% sure that a mastering engineer will take care to finish the record, do some QC and especially keep a human touch to the art. Would a co-mixer be able to do that? possibly, depending on their skillset/experience.

with the use of AI and other systems the expense of hiring a mastering engineer is already fading away but only for projects that are less risky. Say, if you have a tape library of 500 symphonic recordings and need to submit it for streaming so a few folks can listen to it, labels will most likely get an automated system for that to make sure that the standard levels are ok and that it translates well. I'm sure there would be a hungry mastering engineer willing to get that done but the industry is past that era

author: Eric Martin
content:
As long as there’s someone out there that has listened/worked on more music than the person who is the Mixer or Producer and has a “technically better” or more accurate playback system than said producer there will be a viable job for the ME when it comes to releasing music IMO, not everyone will pay to do it, but the people who want to put out the “best work” will, the job will change, it already has many times, but the responsibility will stay.

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

author: jantrit
content: With isolation you’re only as good as the weakest part of your system, that is to say, is the door opening the place where you notice most sound leaking? By the sounds of it yes! First things first can you change it out to a solid core door and add weather stripping and some beefed up stops all the way around? You can get special door seal kits with a droppable bottom seal that seals tight to the floor when the door shuts, although these are like 200 bucks a pop and you can get similar if not better results making something yourself. You want to start by figuring out a rough mass per square foot for your wall assembly (include drywall, stud work, insulation etc) and then bring your door up to the same mass per square foot. Solid core door, good seals all the way around and then you can even add more mass to the door with drywall or plywood. Once your door is at least the same mass per square foot as your wall assembly you’ll have to look elsewhere to gain more isolation

> mastering track, with a complicated plug–in signal chain of UAD Studer A800, Waves Q10 EQ, PSP Vintage Warmer, Waves Linear Phase Multiband, UAD Precision Multiband EQ, Waves L3 Ultramaximizer and another Vintage Warmer, and below that a mix print track.

Running two instances on the master alone 😂 

https://www.soundonsound.com/people/inside-track-alabama-shakes-sound-color?amp

author: timwatt_
content:
Pretty basic question but how do you guys archive production/songwriting sessions?

An artist wants to use a production of mine from 2017 and when I opened up the session to run off the multitrack many of the plugins didn’t load. I’ve been able to download/upgrade/fix most of the heavy movers but some can’t be installed on the current OS. Main culprits are the original Neutron and Vocalsynth (which I was using a lot at the time).

I figure that in this situation I’m going to have to recreate some sounds (which is fine as I’ll be reproducing some of the more dated elements anyway) but it got me thinking about future proofing sessions going forward. It’s made me even consider not using certain plugins in my productions if it’s likely they won’t be supported in the future (*cough* izotope).

I’m sure the solution is as simple as ‘print a multitrack when done’ but if anyone has any other thoughts I’m all ears!

author: spectrummasters
content: Just finishing up the live now . It’s so satisfying to listen to the spotlight being shone on the role that evolutionary biology plays in our perception . Thank you man . And the importance of our physical relationship to sound . I come from a world of outdoor free parties (soundsystems ). Which in America would be akin to something like burning man . My friends ran free party sound systems …..we rocked up to fields in the night and set up massive boxes .

author: spectrummasters
content: Our physical relationship to sound is key . Real  bass is felt in your abdomen , like a thunder clap in a storm . It’s primal and meant to be imo . The sound of a sound system from half a mile away in the night outside . That’s bass . That’s music . We seem to be somewhat obsessed with deconstructing all our evolutionary norms . For the sake of “new tech “ experience s. Your point about the hrtf profiles and the experience of anechoic chambers is so vital imo ruairi!

author: spectrummasters
content: This external factor selecting grouping in animals is the foundation of why animals developed cue signals and calls and in humans why we developed language . Vigilance is corr to our experience of life . So , in the absence of the natural environmental signals we evolved alongside our nervous systems can become stressed without us knowing . A primary signal with respect to a vigilance cue for humans and most animals is birdsong .

author: spectrummasters
content: In nature birds go quiet when there are predators close . These are signals our auditory system evolved to pick up on . It’s core to our experience as animals to provide ourselves with these signals for example . So to hear you bring evolutionary biology into the discussions around atmos is so good man . People need to know this stuff it’s vital to our quality of life experience . In my kitchen I alternate smooth fm (70s/80s classics for the sonics ) or birdsong , for the stress relief . I cannot recommend leaving birdsong on for a few hours in your home enough

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone have recommendations for a good no-nonsense screen recorder app for Mac that they like to use?

I've spent the last 90 minutes trying the *Omi Screen Recorder* and *Record It* and I can't manage to record the system audio, even after installing their audio drivers. Now I'm searching online for alternatives and they seem woefully limited or have fatal flaws. So I thought I'd poll the room because I can't be the first one here to face this.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'm similar. My projects (active work drive) gets backed up hourly on an incremental scheme to a second internal drive. My system drive gets cloned nightly to another internal drive. If either were to fail, I can immediately swap over. The incremental projects drive has saved me countless times when I need to revert some changes or accidentally write-over a cue when I forget to save-as. 

When projects are done, they get backed up to two duplicate hard drives plus an NAS which has copies of all those hard drives but in one place. 

I haven't done the Backblaze thing yet, so I'm still at risk in the event of fire/flood/zombie attack.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm no linguist, but my thinking is that softening certain consonants allows speakers to flow through the words quicker and with less articulation from the tongue. Saying "boddle of wadder" allows your tongue to flow through the sentence quicker than if you reset your tongue to articulate all the hard t's in the same sentence. It feels more stilted that way.

To me it's like writing in cursive versus writing in print. Cursive lettering flows easier at the expense of clarity, but the clearer articulation of print writing is slower.

author: Will Melones
content:
I guess it depends heavily on scale. $40 a month just to keep the doors open sounds steep for an artist who isn't already selling merch at a consistent rate. I haven't looked at Shopify's print on demand pricing, but in general POD is much higher cost than bulk screen printing t-shirts (for example). So if you're a band selling at the scale where $40/mo. on a slow month isn't your *entire* profit margin, it seems like investing in a run of merch would pay for itself.

Now this is completely different if you look at it from the perspective of a clothing brand, where the goal is to have a diversity of designs available at all times, without the need for warehousing and a huge startup cost, and to consistently push sales to a customer base that's devoted to *the merch*. I can't imagine the vast majority of DistroKid artists are going that hard on ecommerce, but they could sure benefit from having their POD merch visible on their Spotify profile. The small artists I work with would probably be better off putting $40 into Instagram ads every month.

author: Rob Domos
content:
The idea that noise shaping can affect how we perceive frequency balance was my first thought for what your concern would be and I can get behind that. 

I’m curious about the statement that “it doesn’t survive further dsp processing”.

My thoughts are: while we typically don’t hear dither as a distinct thing that we can pick out and point to, we do hear the effects of it in the combined signal, and I subjectively feel like each sound in a record has slightly more defined separating edges without dither, and I sometimes subjectively like noise shaping for giving me more of that distinction between elements in the mids. 

(Not that it’s very applicable for me anymore because I stopped dithering 24bit exports about a year ago after some rounds of listening and chatting with a bunch of my friends in the EDM world about it and i’m usually delivering at 24)

author: Josh Bowman
content: Biggest thing for any post audio mix- find out the delivery specs before you mix it (ie broadcast or web only, surround or stereo or both) and setup your mix so your music, dialog, and sfx masters are doing any buss processing and leave your master/mix buss clean aside from final limiter. You wanna make sure the stems add up to the final mix exactly if possible to avoid future shenanigans. Label things very clearly. Otherwise just make it sound good! A lot of ad/agency people like the dialog pretty hot I find.  I’m actually not sure what OMV means. But I’ve been out of the ad mixing game for a few years so maybe I’m blanking. Did it full time briefly tho and delivered a bunch of network stuff so 🤷‍♂️

author: WitnesstheLight
content: According to the manual of the SIR standardCLIP plug-in the highest oversampling option is 256x. This means that the plug-in will increase the sample rate of the signal by 256 times before clipping, and then filter out the unwanted frequencies above the original Nyquist frequency after clipping. This process reduces the distortion and aliasing caused by clipping, and improves the sound quality of the signal. 🤓

author: AJ
content:
Today someone asked about releasing a full album on an artist website as a digital product. The caveat is that singles are released once a month for streaming (full thing on streaming platforms at the end of the year, so the example had 12 singles).  After seeing some good discussion about the idea, I'm curious as to what y'all think about it? 

The main points I've heard in favor of the move:
- 1 person buying the album for 10 bucks cancels out so many no's
- Prioritizes real fans over casual listeners
- Incentivizes an artist to make the album, because it's batching content for a year. 
- Forces the artist to view music as a business, but doesn't fully leave the Spotify ecosystem.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
responding to @SoundsLikeJoe  as well -- 

This exactly. I want to solve problems. Of course if there is something that is very noticeable that can't be resolved convincingly, I will absolutely flag it. Truly, I want the art to be the best it can and almost every single person I've worked with agrees.

BUT -- why wouldn't you just want me to remove a click, attenuate an s, etc? Even did one today where I was removing some high end on just a few clap hits, easy in RX.  Attenuating down the volume of a breath, whatever. Easy. Almost always the result is indistinguishable from you removing it on your end. Then you don't have to reprint, etc etc, the artist gets it faster, everyone wins.

Then there is also the issue of where the click or artifact is actually coming from. Lead vocal? Backgrounds? One of 15 of the background stacks? So much easier for me to just zap the issue on my end from the stereo file. Again, with all this being that the result is equal (and oftentimes better I'd argue)

Obviously if the edit is in the way of connection to the song or it genuinely would sound better as an edit in the mix, we do that. But even something like bridging a bad edit that has a space in an s, etc can be done well with spectral repair replace!

author: Edward Rivera
content:
The problem isn’t that tape is a better medium, it’s that the de facto medium keeps changing. As does the way to connect that medium to a medium reading device. As is the the operating system that reads that medium. As does the playback software that no longer plays back the medium. Etc etc etc. none of these things upgrade in tandem and it’s a bit of a ballache to keep up. We are obviously trying to get to some universal standard but to truly do so would also mean impeding nothing that makes computers great, the constant evolution. 

I do believe tape is a great fantastic option for archival purposes, as is keeping several copies of said thing as Ruairi pointed out. But in the end (like, the _end_ end) a tape will probably serve as the best thing of which to retrieve music off of. If a tape machine isn’t around, one can be _made_ from schematics and parts. Not sure that can be said for building a Mac and Mac OS from scratch

Steve lived through an era where several proprietary digital mediums came and went and the problems that caused for something he deeply cared about

I’ve seen the same in the camera world, where camera bodies from 50-100 years ago are operable or at the very least repairable, while digital 80s and 90s camera bodies serve as paper weights

I think we might see something similar with computers controlled vehicles with proprietary software. But I digress 

Obviously I use digital, if I had the choice, I wouldn’t. But it sure as hell makes a lot of music happen when it otherwise wouldn’t. I just hope it sticks around

content: Like @Bryan DiMaio said, the MacOS scaling is great. In general you want more ppi(pixels per inch) for better quality, you can figure that from the screen size and resolution. I have a 57” 4k tv I’ve used as an aux display before at ~8’ that’s pretty good. The default scaling(HD) is fine for most audio work at that distance, but would probably go down a notch scaling wise for extended text/admin stuff or get a bigger tv. You need HDR on the tv and to enable in system prefs for it to look right with the scaling, otherwise it’s a bunch of banding and moire that’s really annoying ime.

author: Oli J
