Typically wouldn’t do click with subdivision - I run my stems from a full bar and my stem printing code includes the bpm in the folder name. And then committed pro tools mix session for the MD. Artists typically have wildly different click tone preferences on stage to studio so better they adjust that when in rehearsals. 
If there’s a session with tempo map then it’s gonna wind up back in pro tools with an MD either way

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Forgive me if this is obvious, but are you printing either the grouped or separate stems through a final limiter on the mix bus, or just what precedes the limiter? I feel like id want the stems to add up to the final mix, but any dynamics work on the mix bus would yield a different result when processed individually as opposed to the full mix right?

author: Oli J
content: Mix bus yes, limiter no (for both).  Sometimes we have crazy stuff on the mix bus (echoboy or reverbs!) so gotta print through that.

author: Felix Byrne
content: Once stems are printed, I'll pull into a new session, check that everything is playing back correctly, and if needed, adjust any balance things or tonal things that were disrupted by printing separately (usually something like 2 overlapping lead vocals thru the same compressor/multiband that doesn't have ext sc etc)

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
With credits, is there a general consensus or definition on the distinction between  "producer" and "additional production" or is it always a case by case thing? Had a song I worked on (finished the production and did the mix) come out today. At the beginning of the project I had asked to be listed as a producer and mixer but realized when it came out, that the artist had listed himself as the producer and me as additional production/instrumentation, and mixer. The artist is a really good and longtime friend and I am going to just talk to him and ask that he fixes the credits (and will start making written agreements before all of my projects) but I am curious if there is any broader context that could help how I approach the conversation? 

Not super critical to the main question but here are some specifics of my situation: Artist wrote the song, and recorded some basic tracks (drums, vox, guitar). We then worked on it in my studio and I played more instruments (bass, guitars, keys, lap, steel, percussion). We then finished it remotely a few months later. Sent the Ableton production session back and forth a few times times and then I prepped and exported the files myself and mixed it in Protools. And I had to do what I would consider a fair amount of heavy lifting in the mix: song was pretty complicated and recorded at home so I ended up do doing a lot of clean up, some tuning, and a lot of sound shaping and effects. All that to say, this case feels pretty cut and dried but I am curious to know what types of work would appropriately fall under “additional production” and what is standard in the industry. Thanks!

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: masteredbyjack
content: And build systems in your life that encourage the opportunity for deep attentive states (much easier said than done)

author: samvalentine
content:
Hey, I’m not sure where to post this exactly, but I had an interesting experience the other day that I’d like to share with the group and hopefully get some perspective on.

I was touching up a track with a producer friend at the end of a writing session. Vocals and guitar recorded over a 2track beat. I typically throw a Waves L2 on my master, just to bring up the level for the rough bounce, never doing much more than a dB or two of gain reduction. In this case I had the threshold of the L2 set at -3.4. The producer said try -3.5, then back to -3.4, then -3.5… flipping back and forth seeing what he liked more. I couldn’t hear a difference. (I should say that we weren’t in a well treated room, working on some mid sized genelecs. It’s a  setup neither of us is super familiar with.) He decided -3.4 was better and I was in disbelief that he could even hear a difference. I asked if I could do a blind test to see if he could tell which setting was which. He closed his eyes and I switched back and forth a bunch of times before landing on a setting, and he called it correct three times in a row. He said he could hear something in the kick drum but couldn’t explain more than that.
I need a sanity check. I know my ears aren’t hall of fame, but I’m still in disbelief that he was able to tell a .1dB difference in volume on the limiter.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
It does not. Many have done the null test.

DAW specific plugins, different warping algorithms, workflow differences, and some soft clipping differences account for the changes people hear.

If you have reasonable headroom and use the same plugins and use the same bit depth etc etc they are all the same.

author: chrissorem
content: I’m not sure what’s happening, but I’ve taken stems through Cubase and stems through logic with an artist, I work with who works in logic primarily and and it’s been undeniable that there was a difference of what we were hearing.

author: chrissorem
content: No panning was going on just straight stereo stems

author: oaklandmatt
content:
DAWs will sound different if you have different default settings. Panning settings, auto soft clip on export, auto warping, etc etc.

Again, I'm not trying to be dismissive of people, but this stuff has been covered at length here on this discord, as well as many other places on the Internet.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Your response had me reflecting on this, and here's my current perspective.

People spending time online debating the minuscule differences of a DAWs contribution to an export is just another one of those CLASSIC examples of people convincing themselves they are spending their time productively within their field, when they aren't.

I believe that people are most prone to externalizing once they’ve stayed in a plateau long enough. I’ve seen this happen SO many times. Skating with people who blamed losing a competition on not having hollowed trucks. Competed in Street Fighter and had an opponent that blamed the country the parts of their control stick was sourced, saying ‘If only I had ____ parts from South Korea like you…’  It’s hard to look in the mirror and go “You controlled the result. Period. No other factors. Face it. Now do what you need to improve to move forward.” Externalizing seems to be what people do when they are heavily invested in something and can’t surpass a plateau for X amount of time. I see it as more of a ‘lack of personal accountability’ problem, and that anyone can be greater at their callings, as long as they get out of their own way by not focusing their time on pointless comforts/compensations within their field.

Hopefully reflecting on this will further help me avoid time traps along the way too.

My impression is that it started with the British Invasion bands , firstly the Beatles …..coming to America and then not being able to hear themselves on stage for the actual hysterical screaming audiences . Personally , more than the levels it’s the spectral balance for me . I’ve been amongst the sweetest tuned sound systems loud as fcuk and no discomfort or ringing ears whatsoever , and then go to a pub and a speaker by the bar rips my ears off cause it’s all mids .

author: masteredbyjack
content:
It is! Still have yet to find something that ticks all boxes but generally people seem to like delivery some what like:

song
--> FOLDER with ALTS/etc
--> --> INST
--> --> ACA

etc etc

This way pressing the big play button only keys up the main master (or mix, whatever) so the player functions as it would be expected without folders

author: masteredbyjack
content:
The other bug I've had be strange is that sometimes a mixer will share the deliverable folder with me but I can't download it (even though downloads are on). Getting the full project player solves this. Have never had an issue delivering for mastering since it's simple, just a single player shared (never sharing individual parts within a project). But more points to @Rollmottle that Samply is an upstart and can have issues

So good to have an alternative method at the ready should people need. Dropbox solves this for me, it's on my phone at a second's notice. That said I don't think I've had an error pop up in Samply yet. Just sometimes people like the Dropbox for a complicated delivery

author: Kian
content:
as for managing seperate emails in apple mail, its a bit more cumbersome. Initially I was really annoyed by the delay that it took to bounce emails from my @gmail domain to apple mail, but i slowly got used to it. Sometimes emails that get sent to my alternate email show up in apple mail as read which is annoying too. 

Other than that things are okay. Even though you can look at each account's inbox individually, it does put every accounts messages into the main inbox too. If you're just annoyed by having 8000+ unread emails on an account that you generally don't want to receive notifications for, set up a rule to mark any emails in that account as read.

author: Will Trotman
content:
Interesting, that’s good to hear it’s gotten better, I was assuming it had gone the other way. 

I just wonder what kind of disruption could be large enough to cause a shift away from Spotify, since they’re pretty firmly on top. It seems like streaming is about as easy as it’s going to get, and I don’t really hear any Spotify users with qualms about their experience.

I do wonder if artists will become less partial to Spotify over time though. It seems like there are so many different metrics of success now (Spotify streams, instagram followers, tik tok followers are the main ones I think of) that aren’t always mutually inclusive of each other. And I wonder if that takes a little weight off of streaming numbers being the only metric that legitimizes an artist. And I hear people like Ryan Tedder talk about the importance of “world building” for artists now - I wonder if fans of artists will care more about being part of that artist’s ecosystem than the artist’s music being a part of their music library. I think of how K Pop bands sell crazy numbers of physical copies as an example. They can still stream the music but it seems like there are more variables now.

Thinking out loud a little bit, I might have just said absolutely nothing with a lot of words lol.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: We're 10 months in on waiting to get a solar and battery system installed specifically for outages but the solar company has struggled to find a crew in the area to install the system (which they didn't tell us until 6 months into the process). May not end up happening but at least we have the generator

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: In my studio I have almost 10 kW of class D amps. Last I checked my entire studio idled at around 4 amps and with the system going full throttle with atmos it was hitting around 6 amps. That would be around 700 W. When I've had power outages I have had the breaker trip when power comes back on from everything trying to power on at the same time. No clue how much that would theoretically need but if you don't try to turn everything on at the same time, a 1800 W generator should be plenty for most set ups
